questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician with progressively worsening fever, malaise, and a sore throat. Her parents say “Our daughter has not received vaccinations because her body has to learn how to fight infections.” Her temperature is 38.5˚C (101.3 F). Physical examination shows marked cervical lymphadenopathy. There are gray-white membranes over the tonsils and posterior pharynx that bleed when scraped off. The patient's symptoms are most likely caused by disruption of which of the following steps in protein synthesis?

choices.text: Translocation of the ribosome along the mRNA
Binding of tRNA to the A site
Release of completed protein from ribosome

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

After translation has produced a peptide chain, proteins are folded into specific three-dimensional structures. Misfolding of proteins occurs because of factors such as increased body temperature, oxidative stress, or mutations (e.g., chloride channel misfolding in cystic fibrosis). However, diphtheria toxin does not interfere with protein folding.

B) CORRECT:

Ribosomal translocation occurs during the elongation phase of translation, wherein the ribosome moves one triplet at a time along the mRNA in the 3' direction. Diphtheria toxin is a bacterial AB toxin that inactivates the process of translocation by adding a molecule of ADP-ribose to elongation factor 2. EF-2 is then unable to catalyze GTP hydrolysis and fails to provide the ribosome sufficient energy to translocate by one codon. Protein synthesis is subsequently arrested, leading to cell death and necrosis.

Exotoxin A, produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, acts by the same mechanism.
Image Description:

Protein synthesis occurs during elongation: One by one, amino acids are added to form a polypeptide chain. The ribosome (assembled during initiation) reads the mRNA in 5'→3' direction. Each base triplet of the mRNA is translated into an amino acid, which is then added to the C-terminus of the previous amino acid, resulting in a growing chain. The chain's N-terminus (featuring the free amine group) leaves the ribosome first.

1. At the start of elongation, a peptidyl-tRNA (yellow) is located at the P-site of the ribosome. An aminoacyl-tRNA (green) that matches the mRNA at the A-site of the ribosome forms a ternary complex with eukaryotic elongation factor 1 (eEF1) and GTP. If the tRNA anticodon is complementary to the mRNA codon, GTP is hydrolyzed and eEF1 and GDP are released. This process provides the energy for aminoacyl-tRNA to bind to the A-site.

2. The aminoacyl-tRNA (carrying the amino acid that will be added) is now located at the A-site of the ribosome, the peptidyl-tRNA at the P-site. Next, the peptidyl transferase catalyzes the formation of a peptide bond between the amino acids at the A- and P-sites. In the process, the growing polypeptide chain is transferred to the aminoacyl-tRNA at the A-site.

3. During the next step (translocation), the ribosome moves along the mRNA in the 5'→3' direction (for the length of exactly one triplet). Once again, the energy required is derived from GTP hydrolysis (catalyzed by eEF2). The tRNA that was in the A-site is now in the P-site, and the tRNA that was in the P-site is now in the E-site, where it is released.

4. The A-site is now free again and the cycle can be repeated.

C) INCORRECT:

Binding of tRNA to the A site occurs during the elongation phase of translation, whereby a complex of aminoacyl-tRNA and eukaryotic elongation factor 1 binds to matching codons at the A site. Shiga toxin produced by Shigella dysenteriae inhibits protein synthesis by blocking aminoacyl-tRNA binding, leading to failure of protein production and cell death. Diphtheria toxin does not block tRNA binding, though.

D) INCORRECT:

The formation of the initiation complex involves the assembly of ribosomal subunits and the initiator tRNA at the start codon. Molecules such as the antibiotic linezolid or toxins produced by E. coli (YoeB, RatA toxins) block the formation of the initiation complex, inhibiting protein synthesis and causing cell death. However, diphtheria toxin does not produce its effects through inhibition of the initiation complex.

E) INCORRECT:

Post-translational modifications (PTMs) involve the covalent addition of chemical groups (phosphorylation, methylation, ubiquitination, etc.) to proteins. This is done in order to affect protein folding, change solubility, or influence enzymatic activity, among many other results. Legionella pneumophila is an example of a bacteria that interferes with PTMs of the host cell, escaping host defenses, and hijacking cellular processes. Diphtheria toxin does not interfere with PTMs.

F) INCORRECT:

The release of completed proteins from ribosomes occurs during termination of the translation process. Release factors recognize the stop codon and hydrolytically cleave the final peptidyl-tRNA, freeing the amino acid chain. Diphtheria toxin does not interfere with protein release but disrupts a different stage of protein synthesis.
questions.hint: An unvaccinated patient presenting with fever, malaise, severe lymphadenopathy, and sore throat with grayish-white pharyngeal pseudomembranes is diagnostic of infection with Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: An investigator studying protein synthesis in human stem cells isolates tRNA molecules bound to mRNA molecules. The isolated tRNA molecules have inosine in the 5' position of the anticodon; of these, some are bound to adenine, some to cytosine, and some to uracil at the 3' position of the mRNA codon. Which of the following properties of the genetic code is best illustrated by this finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Specificity of the start codon refers to the unique ability of the AUG start codon to initiate translation of an mRNA strand. This concept does not relate to the ability of one anticodon to bind to multiple codons.

B) INCORRECT:

Specificity of stop codons refers to the principle that only three stop codons (UAG, UAA, UGA) signal the end of translation. This concept does not relate to the ability of one anticodon to bind to multiple codons.

C) CORRECT:

Degeneracy (genetic code) refers to the redundancy of codon base pairing; multiple codons can specify one single amino acid. During translation, some tRNA molecules can recognize multiple codons because of flexibility between the pairing of the 3' nucleotide of the codon (the wobble position) with the 5' nucleotide of the anticodon, which usually contains inosine (hypoxanthine nucleoside) instead of the usual nucleotides. Degeneracy reduces the extent of damage caused by DNA mutations.

There are two amino acids that are encoded by only one codon: methionine (AUG) and tryptophan (UGG).
Image Description:

During translation, the codon on mRNA is recognized by the anticodon on tRNA in the ribosome, resulting in incorporation of the correctly encoded amino acid in the growing polypeptide. For interaction between the codon and the anticodon, the first nucleotide of the anticodon (nucleotide at the 5' end) determines whether it can pair with one, two, or even three different nucleotides at the 3' end of the codon. The third position at the 5' end of the anticodon is termed wobble position, because of the certain degree of flexibility (“wobble”) in base pairing. The nucleotide inosine (I) is usually found at the wobble position.

D) INCORRECT:

Unambiguity (genetic code) refers to the specificity of the genetic code; each codon corresponds to only one anticodon, and therefore, only one amino acid. Unambiguity does not relate to the ability of one anticodon to bind to multiple codons.

E) INCORRECT:

Non-overlapping (genetic code) refers to the sequential and continuous translation of codons. Each codon of an mRNA strand is translated in the 5' → 3' direction, beginning with the start codon (which sets an open reading frame) and ending with the stop codon; three bases are read at a time. Non-overlapping does not relate to the ability of one anticodon to bind to multiple codons.

F) INCORRECT:

Universality (genetic code) refers to the similarity of the genetic code among multiple organisms. A few exceptions to universality are found in mitochondria, Mycoplasma, archaebacteria, and some yeasts, all of which have alternative codon-amino acid translations. Universality does not relate to the ability of one anticodon to bind to multiple codons.
questions.hint: The finding describes the biochemical mechanism that underlies the wobble hypothesis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of recurrent respiratory infections and difficulty walking for 2 months. Physical examination shows numerous telangiectasias on the nose, ears, and neck. There is overshoot on the finger-to-nose test. He has a narrow-based gait. Genetic analysis shows a nonsense mutation in the ataxia-telangiectasia gene (ATM gene). Sequencing of the encoded truncated protein shows that the C-terminal amino acid is tryptophan. The last correctly incorporated amino acid is most likely encoded by which of the following mRNA codons?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

5'UAA3' is a stop codon. It does not encode an amino acid; stop codons end translation.

B) INCORRECT:

5'AUG3' is the start codon, which encodes methionine. Each polypeptide initially starts with methionine, but in most cases, the N-terminal methionine is cleaved by methionine aminopeptidase during translation. Methionine can also be incorporated into the growing polypeptide chain. Although it is possible to have a methionine as the final amino acid incorporated, this protein has been sequenced and does not have methionine at the C-terminal end.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has a nonsense mutation that has created a new stop codon; protein translation up to this point is unaffected. The mRNA codon 5'UGG3' encodes tryptophan. Since nonsense mutations can occur at any point within the gene, the correct answer could have corresponded to any amino acid (except methionine, as indicated). However, all other answer choices correspond to either start or stop codons. The amino acids tryptophan and methionine (5'AUG3') are unique in that they are each encoded by only one codon, unlike all other amino acids.

This patient has ataxia-telangiectasia, a condition caused by a defect in nonhomologous end joining that manifests with cerebellar defects (ataxia, overshoot on the finger-to-nose test), telangiectasias, and IgA deficiency (which results in recurrent mucosal infections).
Image Description:

During translation, the codon on mRNA is recognized by the anticodon on tRNA in the ribosome, resulting in incorporation of the correctly encoded amino acid in the growing polypeptide. For interaction between the codon and the anticodon, the first nucleotide of the anticodon (nucleotide at the 5' end) determines whether it can pair with one, two, or even three different nucleotides at the 3' end of the codon. The third position at the 5' end of the anticodon is termed wobble position, because of the certain degree of flexibility (“wobble”) in base pairing. The nucleotide inosine (I) is usually found at the wobble position.

D) INCORRECT:

5'UGA3' is a stop codon. It does not encode an amino acid; stop codons end translation.

E) INCORRECT:

5'UAG3' is a stop codon. It does not encode an amino acid; stop codons end translation.
questions.hint: It is not necessary to know the codons of all amino acids to answer this question correctly. All incorrect answer options are either start or stop codons. Thus, only one answer option corresponds to an amino acid that is not methionine.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a rash and headache. She recently returned from a camping trip in North Carolina. She has a severe allergy to doxycycline. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Physical examination shows a blanching erythematous rash and petechiae over both ankles and the soles of her feet. A drug is prescribed that can cause fatal aplastic anemia. The bacteriostatic effect of this drug is most likely due to which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Inhibition of initiation complex formation at the 30S ribosomal subunit
Inactivation of prokaryotic topoisomerase II and IV
Inhibition of tRNA binding site at the 30S ribosomal subunit
Inhibition of peptide translocation at the 50S ribosomal subunit
Inactivation of bacterial peptidyltransferase at the 50S ribosomal subunit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline) and aminoglycosides inhibit the formation of the initiation complex at the 30S subunit of the ribosome in bacteria. While doxycycline is the first-line treatment for infection with R. rickettsii, this patient has a severe allergy to the drug. Aminoglycosides are primarily used to treat severe gram-negative infections, not atypical bacteria like R. rickettsii. Moreover, neither tetracyclines nor aminoglycosides cause aplastic anemia. The side effects of tetracyclines include discoloration of bones and teeth in children and photosensitivity. The side effects of aminoglycosides include nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, and neuromuscular blockade.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluoroquinolones are bactericidal antibiotics that inhibit bacterial topoisomerase II and topoisomerase IV. They are used to treat atypical pneumonia (e.g., Legionella pneumophila, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and Chlamydophila pneumoniae), anaerobic infections, and urinary tract infections, but not RMSF. Furthermore, while the side effects of fluoroquinolones include cartilage damage in children, tendon rupture, and QT prolongation, they are not known to cause aplastic anemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline) inhibit aminoacyl-tRNA binding to the 30S subunit of the ribosome, thereby inhibiting the formation of the ribosomal initiation complex in bacteria. While doxycycline is the first-line treatment for R. rickettsii, as well as for other atypical bacteria (e.g., Borrelia burgdorferi, Mycoplasma pneumoniae), this patient has a severe allergy to it. Moreover, tetracyclines do not cause aplastic anemia. The side effects of tetracyclines include discoloration of bones and teeth in children and photosensitivity.

D) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin and macrolides are bacteriostatic antibiotics that bind the 50S subunit of ribosomes in bacteria and inhibit ribosomal translocation. Macrolides are used to treat atypical pneumonia (e.g., Legionella, Mycoplasma) and STIs (e.g., Chlamydia), and clindamycin is used to treat anaerobic infections (e.g., Clostridia, Bacteroides). Neither of these antibiotics is used to treat RMSF or causes aplastic anemia. The side effects of clindamycin include pseudomembranous colitis and gastritis. The side effects of macrolides include diarrhea, QT prolongation, cholestasis, rash, and drug interactions due to CYP450 inhibition.

E) CORRECT:

Chloramphenicol is a bacteriostatic antibiotic that inhibits peptidyltransferase at the 50S subunit of the ribosome in bacteria. Although it can be used to treat both bacterial meningitis (e.g., H. influenzae, N. meningitidis, and/or S. pneumoniae) and RMSF (R. rickettsii), it is rarely used due to the risk of aplastic anemia and gray baby syndrome in newborns. It was administered to this patient because she has an allergy to doxycycline, which is usually the first-line therapy for RMSF.
Image Description:

Multiple, partly confluent, macules are visible on this patient's forearm.

This rash is suggestive of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), a tick-borne disease caused by Rickettsia rickettsii bacteria. The distal extremities are usually affected first; the rash then spreads toward the proximal extremities and the trunk (the face, however, is usually spared).
questions.hint: Headache, fever, and petechial rash on the palms and soles that spreads proximally is the classic triad of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF). North Carolina is one of the states in which RMSF is most common. Chloramphenicol is an anti-rickettsial known to cause aplastic anemia, because of which it is no longer commonly used.

questions.text: An investigator is developing a new vaccine. Eukaryote ribosomes are utilized to create a novel protein. After the aminoacyl-tRNA binds to the A site, which of the following is the next step in protein formation?

choices.text: Recognition of UAG codon by release factor

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The second step of the elongation phase of protein synthesis is marked by the formation of the peptide bond by the ribozyme peptidyl transferase, which is intrinsic to the rRNA of the large ribosomal complex. This peptide bond is formed between the amino group of the new amino acid in the A site and the carboxyl group of the growing polypeptide chain in the P site of the ribosome.

Certain antibiotic drugs, including macrolides (e.g., erythromycin), block the peptidyl transferase center located at the 50S ribosomal subunit, thereby inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis.
Image Description:

Protein synthesis occurs during elongation: One by one, amino acids are added to form a polypeptide chain. The ribosome (assembled during initiation) reads the mRNA in 5'→3' direction. Each base triplet of the mRNA is translated into an amino acid, which is then added to the C-terminus of the previous amino acid, resulting in a growing chain. The chain's N-terminus (featuring the free amine group) leaves the ribosome first.

1. At the start of elongation, a peptidyl-tRNA (yellow) is located at the P-site of the ribosome. An aminoacyl-tRNA (green) that matches the mRNA at the A-site of the ribosome forms a ternary complex with eukaryotic elongation factor 1 (eEF1) and GTP. If the tRNA anticodon is complementary to the mRNA codon, GTP is hydrolyzed and eEF1 and GDP are released. This process provides the energy for aminoacyl-tRNA to bind to the A-site.

2. The aminoacyl-tRNA (carrying the amino acid that will be added) is now located at the A-site of the ribosome, the peptidyl-tRNA at the P-site. Next, the peptidyl transferase catalyzes the formation of a peptide bond between the amino acids at the A- and P-sites. In the process, the growing polypeptide chain is transferred to the aminoacyl-tRNA at the A-site.

3. During the next step (translocation), the ribosome moves along the mRNA in the 5'→3' direction (for the length of exactly one triplet). Once again, the energy required is derived from GTP hydrolysis (catalyzed by eEF2). The tRNA that was in the A-site is now in the P-site, and the tRNA that was in the P-site is now in the E-site, where it is released.

4. The A-site is now free again and the cycle can be repeated.

B) INCORRECT:

The final step of protein synthesis (e.g., termination) occurs when the release factor recognizes a stop codon (UGA, UAG, or UAA) on the mRNA. This step marks the end of translation and results in the release of the completed polypeptide chain from the ribosomal complex. However, this is not the step that directly follows aminoacyl-tRNA binding to the A site.
Image Description:

The codon wheel is a representation of the genetic code. It shows which mRNA codon translates into which amino acid. The wheel is read from the inside (5' end) to the outside (3' end). For example, the triplet UAC codes for the amino acid tyrosine (Tyr). Start codons are shown as triangles, while stop codons are shown as squares.

C) INCORRECT:

Assembly of the 40S ribosomal subunit with the initiator tRNA occurs during the initiation phase of protein synthesis. This step must occur before aminoacyl-tRNA can bind to the A site of the ribosome.
Image Description:

Translation starts with the initiation phase, during which the eukaryotic ribosomes (80S) are formed. Eukaryotic ribosome is a complex of the 60S and 40S ribosomal subunits. At the P site of the eukaryotic ribosome, the methionine-carrying initiator tRNA binds to the start codon of the mRNA transcript. This initiation complex is capable of linking the required peptide bonds during the subsequent elongation phase in translation, which allows for the synthesis of a peptide or protein.

D) INCORRECT:

Advancement of the ribosomal complex from the 5' end towards the 3′ end of the mRNA occurs as the peptidyl tRNA is moved from the A site to the P site. This process is the third step of the elongation phase of protein synthesis, but it is not the step that directly follows aminoacyl-tRNA binding to the A site.

E) INCORRECT:

Binding of mRNA with the 60S ribosomal subunit occurs during the initiation phase of protein synthesis. Afterwards, the large and small ribosomal subunits assemble into a functional ribosome (the final initiation complex; 40S + 60S = 80S in eukaryotes, 30S + 50S = 70S in prokaryotes). These steps must occur before aminoacyl-tRNA can bind to the A site of the ribosome.
Image Description:

Translation starts with the initiation phase, during which the eukaryotic ribosomes (80S) are formed. Eukaryotic ribosome is a complex of the 60S and 40S ribosomal subunits. At the P site of the eukaryotic ribosome, the methionine-carrying initiator tRNA binds to the start codon of the mRNA transcript. This initiation complex is capable of linking the required peptide bonds during the subsequent elongation phase in translation, which allows for the synthesis of a peptide or protein.
questions.hint: Binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the aminoacyl site (A site) of the ribosome is the first step of the elongation process during translation.

questions.text: An investigator is following a 4-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Western blot of skeletal muscle cells from this boy shows that the dystrophin protein is significantly smaller compared to the dystrophin protein of a healthy subject. Further evaluation shows that the boy's genetic mutation involves a sequence that normally encodes leucine. The corresponding mRNA codon has the sequence UUG. Which of the following codons is most likely present in this patient at the same position of the mRNA sequence?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A single base transition of guanine to adenine would result in a silent mutation as the encoded amino acid, leucine, would not be changed. This is due to the redundancy in the genetic code, which gives a degree of protection against point mutations. As such, there is neither loss of function nor change of structure of the protein due to this mutation.

B) INCORRECT:

A single base transversion of uracil to guanine would result in a missense mutation, where leucine replaces valine. Although valine is a bulkier branched amino acid, both the AAs are nonpolar molecules, and such a replacement would most likely result in a conservative mutation with neither loss of function nor change in protein length.

C) INCORRECT:

A single base transversion of uracil to adenosine would result in a replacement of leucine with methionine, a missense mutation. As both the AAs are nonpolar aliphatic molecules, such a replacement would most likely result in a conservative mutation with neither loss of function nor change in protein length.

AUG is also the signal codon which initiates the translation of the mRNA. Therefore, every polypeptide initially starts with methionine, but in most cases, the N-terminal methionine is cleaved by methionine aminopeptidase during translation.

D) CORRECT:

A single base transversion from uracil to adenine results in the premature stop codon UAG, i.e., a nonsense mutation, leading to the truncated protein production. The shorter amino acid chain does not fold in the same manner as the wild-type protein, resulting in a change in the three-dimensional structure of the proteins. Consequently, the function of this truncated, misfolded protein is lost. To help remember the 3 different stop codons UGA, UAG, and UAA: U Go Away, U Are Gone, and U Are Away.
Image Description:

The codon wheel is a representation of the genetic code. It shows which mRNA codon translates into which amino acid. The wheel is read from the inside (5' end) to the outside (3' end). For example, the triplet UAC codes for the amino acid tyrosine (Tyr). Start codons are shown as triangles, while stop codons are shown as squares.

E) INCORRECT:

A single base transversion of uracil to guanine would result in a replacement of leucine with tryptophan, a missense mutation. Although tryptophan is a bulkier aromatic amino acid, both the AAs are nonpolar molecules, and such a replacement would most likely result in a conservative mutation with neither loss of function nor change in protein length.

F) INCORRECT:

A single base transversion of guanine to uracil would result in a replacement of leucine with phenylalanine, a missense mutation. Although phenylalanine is a bulkier aromatic amino acid, both the AAs are nonpolar molecules, and such a replacement would most likely result in a conservative mutation with neither loss of function nor change in protein length.

G) INCORRECT:

A single base transition of uracil to cytosine results in a replacement of leucine with serine. The replacement of a nonpolar aliphatic AA (Leu) with an uncharged polar AA (Ser) represents a nonconservative missense mutation, which could affect the three-dimensional structure of the protein, as hydrophilic amino acids tend to settle on the protein surface during folding. However, a missense mutation would not lead to the production of shorter proteins.
questions.hint: The patient's truncated dystrophin protein most likely involves a point mutation creating a premature stop codon.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the genotypes of wingless fruit flies using full exome sequencing. Compared to wild-type winged fruit flies, the wingless fruit flies are found to have a point mutation in the gene encoding wing bud formation during embryogenesis. The point mutation in the gene causes the mRNA transcript to have a 'UUG' segment instead of an 'AUG' segment. Which of the following processes is most likely affected by this mutation?

choices.text: Shift of peptidyl-tRNA from A to P site
Dissociation of mRNA from ribosome complex

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The binding of methionine-tRNA to the 60S subunit is the initiating event in translation and requires the AUG start codon. At this codon, the 60S ribosomal subunit binds with the pre-initiation complex, forming the complete 80s initiation complex and allowing translation to commence. A point mutation that changes AUG to UUG would result in the addition of a leucine molecule instead of methionine, which would prevent this step. As a result, a key protein involved in the embryogenesis of wing bud formation would not be synthesized.
Image Description:

Translation in eukaryotes begins with initiation. First, the small ribosomal subunit (40S) combines with specific initiation factors. This prevents premature joining of small and large subunits. The ternary complex of methionine-loaded initiator tRNA, initiation factor eIF-2, and GTP binds to the small ribosomal subunit and forms the 43S preinitiation complex. The mRNA recognized by eIF-4 binds to the 43S preinitiation complex, resulting in the 48S preinitiation complex. Initiator tRNA recognizes the start codon (usually the first AUG triplet after the 5' cap of mRNA). GTP hydrolysis leads to the release of eIF-2-GDP. The large and small ribosomal subunits merge to form the 80S ribosome, the final initiation complex (eukaryotic ribosome).

B) INCORRECT:

The shift of peptidyl-tRNA from the ribosomal A site (initial binding site of peptidyl-tRNA) to the P site (second binding site of peptidyl-tRNA) is a part of peptide elongation. Although impaired shifting from the A site to the P site would inhibit peptide synthesis and lead to a defect in embryogenesis, a point mutation from AUG to UUG would not affect this process.

C) INCORRECT:

Dissociation of mRNA from the ribosome translation complex occurs at a stop codon sequence (UAG, UAA, or UGA), which is recognized by a release factor that hydrolytically cleaves the peptidyl tRNA bonds of the translation complex, resulting in its release. Although a nonsense mutation would result in an early stop codon and inhibit proper protein synthesis, a point mutation from AUG to UUG would not result in a premature stop codon and translation complex dissociation.

D) INCORRECT:

Catalyzation of peptide bond formation is performed by ribozymes in the active site of ribosomes (the peptidyl-transferase center). Although impaired peptide bond formation could lead to a defect in embryogenesis, the point mutation of AUG to UUG would not affect the catalytic processes of the ribosome.

E) INCORRECT:

Cleavage of 5' introns is a post-transcriptional modification that occurs through splicing of introns, resulting in mature mRNA. The major spliceosome recognizes introns by a GU sequence at the 5' splice site and an AG at the 3' splice site. A point mutation causing AUG to become UUG would therefore not affect splicing.
questions.hint: The AUG codon not only codes for a specific amino acid but also serves a crucial function in RNA biology.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the activity of N-terminal peptidase in eukaryotes. Sulfur-containing amino acids are radiolabeled and isolated using 35S. During translation of a nonmitochondrial human genome, some of the radiolabeled amino acids bind to the aminoacyl, peptidyl, and exit sites of a eukaryotic ribosome; others bind only to the peptidyl and exit sites. Only the radiolabeled amino acids that do not bind to the ribosomal aminoacyl-site can be excised by the N-terminal peptidase. Which of the following best describes the anticodon sequence of the transfer RNA charged by the amino acid target of the N-terminal peptidase?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The 5'-UCA-3' anticodon corresponds to a 5'-UGA-3' codon, which is a stop codon. No known aminoacyl-tRNA binds to a stop codon; therefore, 5'-UGA-3' does not code an amino acid.

B) CORRECT:

The eukaryotic mRNA start codon is 5'-AUG-3', which is bound by a methionyl-tRNA that contains the complementary 5'-CAU-3' anticodon during the initiation of translation. The first methionine is subsequently removed by an N-terminal peptidase as a part of the cotranslational or posttranslational modification, while all other sulfur-containing amino acids are not excised. Methionine can also be incorporated into the middle of the protein, in which case the methionyl-tRNA would bind to the A site. However, methionine in the middle of the strand would not be targeted by the N-terminal peptidase. The eukaryotic mitochondrial genome start codons also include 5'-AUA-3' and 5'-AUU-3' (both isoleucine), which correspond to the anticodons 5'-UAU-3' and 5'-AAU-3' respectively.
Image Description:

The codon wheel is a representation of the genetic code. It shows which mRNA codon translates into which amino acid. The wheel is read from the inside (5' end) to the outside (3' end). For example, the triplet UAC codes for the amino acid tyrosine (Tyr). Start codons are shown as triangles, while stop codons are shown as squares.

C) INCORRECT:

The 5'-ACA-3' anticodon corresponds to a 5'-UGU-3' codon, which codes for cysteine. Cysteine is a sulfur-containing amino acid. However, the N-terminal peptidase can only cleave amino acids that bind the P and E sites without binding the A site, which only occurs in the case of amino acids that are coded by the start codon, and 5'-UGU-3' codon is not the eukaryotic start codon.

D) INCORRECT:

The 5'-ACU-3' anticodon corresponds to a 5'-AGU-3' codon, which codes for serine. Serine is not a sulfur-containing amino acid; therefore, it would not be radiolabelled in this experiment. Moreover, the N-terminal peptidase can only cleave amino acids that bind the P and E sites without binding the A site, which only occurs in the case of amino acids that are coded by the start codon, and 5'-AGU-3' codon is not the eukaryotic start codon.

E) INCORRECT:

The 5'-UAC-3' anticodon corresponds to a 5'-GUA-3' codon, which codes for valine. Valine is not a sulfur-containing amino acid; therefore, it would not be radiolabelled in this experiment. Moreover, the N-terminal peptidase can only cleave amino acids that bind the P and E sites without binding the A site, which only occurs in the case of amino acids that are coded by the start codon, and 5'-GUA-3' codon is not the eukaryotic start codon.
questions.hint: The sulfur-containing amino acids are cysteine and methionine. In eukaryotes, the tRNA with an anticodon that is complementary to the start codon is charged with methionine. While aminoacyl-tRNAs usually shift between the aminoacyl (A), peptidyl (P), and exit (E) sites of the ribosome during translation, the methionyl-tRNA is the only tRNA that does not bind to the A site.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the function of the endoplasmic reticulum in genetically modified lymphocytes. A gene is removed that facilitates the binding of ribosomes to the endoplasmic reticulum. Which of the following processes is most likely to be impaired as a result of this genetic modification?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Proteins in the cytosol can be synthesized by free ribosomes, which do not interact with the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). Therefore, the synthesis of cytosolic proteins would not be affected by a gene defect that prevents the binding of ribosomes to ER.

B) CORRECT:

The production of secretory proteins (e.g., antibodies) in the rough endoplasmic reticulum (rER) requires binding between the rER and the ribosome. The propeptides of secretory proteins have a binding site for the signal recognition particle (SRP); binding of the SRP to the propeptide halts protein translation (elongation arrest) in the ribosome until the entire ribosome-mRNA complex with its growing propeptide chain approaches the rER. Translation of the secretory protein cannot be completed if the ribosome cannot bind to the rER, as is the case with these genetically modified lymphocytes.
Image Description:

Some proteins, e.g., secretory proteins, possess a signal sequence (amino acid sequence of 9–12 amino acids) by which they are transported to their destination during synthesis (cotranslational transport).

(1) Translation begins on free ribosomes in the cytosol, with the assembly of ribosomal subunits on mRNA.

(2) Synthesis of a signal sequence results in its binding to a signal recognition particle (SRP).

(3) SRP stops translation and binds to the SRP receptor on the ER membrane.

(4) SRP and the SRP receptor are bound to GTP, which is hydrolyzed to GDP after binding. In this way, the ribosome is transferred to the translocon, a protein complex traversing the ER membrane that subsequently opens like a canal. SRP is released and can be recycled.

(5) Translation continues and the protein is directly synthesized in the ER lumen.

(6) During translation, the signal sequence is cleaved from the growing protein. The resulting peptide exits the translocon laterally into the membrane, where it is subsequently degraded.

(7) After termination of translation, the ribosome is released into the cytosol.

(8) The translocon channel closes and the synthesized protein remains in the ER.

Lysosomal proteins and membrane proteins are synthesized similarly in the rough ER. However, membrane proteins exit the translocon laterally, directly into the ER membrane, as insoluble proteins.

C) INCORRECT:

The synthesis of ketone bodies occurs in the mitochondrion. These molecules are then released into the circulation to act as an energy source during times of fasting. Mitochondrial functions are not affected by ribosomal binding to the endoplasmic reticulum.

D) INCORRECT:

α-oxidation of fatty acids occurs in the acidic environment of the peroxisome. The proteins that perform peroxisomal functions are produced by free ribosomes in the cytosol. A genetic modification that impairs ribosome binding to the endoplasmic reticulum would be unlikely to have an effect on peroxisomal function.

E) INCORRECT:

Neutralization of toxins is predominantly a function of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER), which is also the site of steroid hormone synthesis. Ribosomes do not bind to the SER. Therefore, the function of the SER would not be affected in these genetically modified lymphocytes.

F) INCORRECT:

Ubiquitination is a post-translational protein modification that occurs predominantly in the cytosol, nucleoplasm, and mitochondria. This process is integral to the destruction and removal of protein products from the cell. Ubiquitination is impaired in certain diseases, including von Hippel Lindau disease (impaired ubiquitination of hypoxia-inducible factor 1), autosomal recessive juvenile Parkinsonism (inhibition of parkin), and certain malignancies (impaired ubiquitination of oncogenic proteins). Ubiquitination does not occur in ribosomes or the endoplasmic reticulum.
questions.hint: Plasma cells are rich in rough endoplasmic reticulum because they must produce antibodies.
